awd_abstract_narration:
A critical barrier to progress in understanding the nervous organization of movements, the defining capacity of animals, is a paucity of data on the function of connections between neurons within motor-related networks, particularly in intact freely behaving mammals. The proposed study will fill this gap by revealing inter-neuronal interactions in the cortical circuitry for control of visually guided locomotion. Thereby it will make a critical step toward a mechanistic understanding of the cortical mechanisms underlying complex everyday movements. Accomplishing the aims of this project will constitute a substantial advancement in mammalian motor neurophysiology and will have direct impact on and can be transformative for understanding the basic principles of how vision is used to adapt movements. In addition, data from this project will be added to open databases of brain structure and function to further facilitate research of the brain. This will ultimately lead to a better understanding of neurological disorders affecting vision and movements and development of new treatments for them. The project will also have an educational impact by providing students at various levels an opportunity to participate in research. 


The specific goal of this project is to understand the motor, premotor, and parietal cortex mechanisms that are involved in adaptation of locomotion to the visually perceived features of complex natural environments. Experimental data will be obtained from cats, which are classic subjects for research in both motor and visual systems. Cats will walk on a flat surface where no visuo-motor coordination will be required and along a horizontal ladder where visuo-motor coordination for accurate foot placement on the cross-pieces will be required. Visual information will be made available to cats at different phases of the approach. The activity of neurons in the motor, premotor, and parietal cortex will be recorded. Axonal projections of the neurons will be identified. Optogenetic tools will be then used to reversibly block or activate various inputs to the neurons in order to understand the contribution that these inputs make to the formation of cortico-spinal signals for control of visually guided stepping. There are two interlocking objectives. Objective 1 is to reveal the role of projection from posterior parietal area 5 to premotor cortex in modulation of its descending signals during simple and visually-guided locomotion. Objective 2 is to reveal the role of projection from premotor area 6 to motor cortex in modulation of motor cortical signals to the spinal cord during simple and visually-guided locomotion. Results will provide novel insights into the basic neural principles of perception to action conversion during the defining function of animals, locomotion.

por.por_cntn:
An efficient adjustment of locomotion to features of the environment is important for the majority of everyday activities. However, the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. In this project, we took several critical steps to better understand the cortical neuronal mechanisms involved in adaptation of locomotion to visually perceived characteristics of the environment.

Vision plays an important role in guiding locomotion in complex environments, but the coordination between gaze and stride is not well understood. We analyzed the coordination of gaze shifts, fixations, constant gaze, and slow gaze with strides in walking cats. We found that gaze behaviors are coordinated with strides even when walking on a flat surface in complete darkness. They occur in a sequential order during different phases of the stride. During walking on a complex surface, gaze behaviors are more tightly coordinated with strides, particularly at faster speeds, only slightly shifting in phase. These findings indicate that the coordination of gaze behaviors with strides is not vision-driven, but is a part of the whole body locomotion synergy; the visual environment and locomotor task modulate it (Zubair et al., 2019). In cats walking on the complex surface of a horizontally placed ladder, we showed that visual information required for accurate steps is collected non-uniformly throughout the stride. Brief denial of visual input during a forelimb swing prolongs the next stance of that limb. Denial of visual input during a forelimb stance prolongs this stance and the next stride of this limb. Denial during the first half of a stance has a greater effect than during second half. The stride phase dependence of the use of vision for accurate steps and the pattern of affected swings and stances are closely related to the pattern of gaze behavior (Volgushev et al., 2022).

Area 5 of parietal cortex is part of the "dorsal stream" cortical pathway which processes visual information for action, including accurate steps. The signals that area 5 conveys to motor cortex, the main cortical area providing output to the spinal cord, are poorly understood. We analyzed area 5 neuronal activity during vision-independent locomotion on a flat surface and vision-guided stepping on a horizontally placed ladder in cats, focusing on the activity of corticocortical neurons (CCs) that project axons to motor cortex from the upper and deeper cortical layers. We compared this activity to that of neighboring unidentified neurons (noIDs). We found that upon transition from vision-independent to vision-guided stepping, the low discharge of CCs in  layer V doubles and proportion of cells with two bursts per stride tends to increase. The group of two-bursters develops two activity peaks that coincide with peaks of gaze shifts along the surface. One-bursters and either subpopulation in supragranular layers do not transmit any unified stride-related signal to motor cortex. The activity pattern of most CC groups does not mirror that of noID counterparts. CCs with receptive fields on the shoulder, elbow, or wrist/paw discharge in opposite phases with respective groups of pyramidal tract neurons of motor cortex, the cortico-spinal cells (Beloozerova et al., 2023). These findings mean that area 5 CCs transmit to motor cortex specialized signals and suggest that these signals contribute to the stride phase-related inhibition of cortico-spinal cells, thereby setting their firing pattern. This pattern ultimately determines limb movement.

Participation of a large cortical area, the premotor cortex, in visual control of steps on a complex natural surface was not previously examined. We analyzed the activity of neurons in feline premotor area 6 as cats walked on a flat surface where visual guidance of steps was not needed and stepped along a horizontally placed ladder or over barriers where visual control of steps was required. The comparison of neuronal firing between vision-dependent and vision-independent stepping revealed components of the activity related to visual guidance of steps. We found that the firing activity of 59% of neurons is modulated with the rhythm of strides on the flat surface, and the activity of 83-86% of the population changes upon transition to locomotion on the ladder or with barriers. The firing rate and the depth of stride-related activity modulation of 33-44% of neurons changes, and the stride phases where neurons prefer to fire changes for 58-73% of neurons. We concluded that premotor cortex neurons participate in the cortical network supporting visual control of steps by modifying the phase, intensity, and salience of their firing activity. Comparison of this activity to that of several other cortical areas sending axons to the spinal cord showed that all areas contribute simultaneously but differently to the task of making the strides on a complex surface accurate (Viana Di Prisco et al., 2023).

The new knowledge gained in result of this project opens new perspectives for research into neuronal mechanisms of cortical control of locomotion and visuomotor coordination in general, and for better understanding related neurological disorders.
